reinforcements.similarity: Both address what happens at the moment a host encounters an unfamiliar or threatening transition. The library's System 1 Trust Gate prescribes passing an automatic legitimacy check at every phase transition through visual consistency and familiar language. This run's Similar-Other Proof at Every Norm-Breaking Moment prescribes surfacing peer evidence at every point the platform deviates from the host's established norm. Both solve the same root problem -- the host's automatic rejection of unfamiliar stimuli -- but through complementary mechanisms: the library element uses visual/linguistic continuity, this run's element uses social proof from similar others.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence (Kahneman): System 1 rejects transitions that feel unfamiliar; the solution is associative coherence with the prior phase. New evidence (Cialdini + John): the host rejects norm-breaking terms not because they are visually unfamiliar but because no peers have validated them; the solution is social proof from similar others. Combined insight: phase transitions that introduce norm-breaking terms need BOTH visual continuity (System 1 trust gate) AND peer evidence (social proof). Visual consistency alone fails when the content itself is norm-breaking, as John's call proves -- the conversation was perfectly coherent, but the content violated his social norm. The two elements are complementary layers of the same defense against automatic rejection.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the critical handoff gap where platform trust must be established or maintained. The library's Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming focuses on the agent-to-platform transition: the agent should prime the digital experience during the call, and the platform should echo the call. This run's Directed Next Step Assignment focuses on the call-to-follow-up transition: every unresolved call must end with a specific who/what/when commitment. Both solve the same structural problem -- trust evaporates in the gap between interactions -- but at different scales.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence (Kahneman): the platform must reference the agent and the call to inherit trust. New evidence (Cialdini + John): Bryant's vague 'I'll talk to our team' created a dead-end where trust dissipated because no specific commitment bridged the gap. Combined insight: continuity priming (mentioning the platform during the call, showing the agent on the platform) is necessary but not sufficient. Even with perfect priming, an unresolved objection with no directed next step kills conversion. The bridge must have both structural continuity AND specific commitments to survive the gap between interactions.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the problem of cognitive overload in multi-step evaluations. The library's Design for the Depleted User prescribes reducing decisions per phase, providing smart defaults, and inserting decompression moments. This run's Two-Layer Evaluation Separation prescribes splitting tenant evaluation from platform-terms evaluation so that a negative reaction to one does not contaminate the other. Both recognize that the host's cognitive resources are limited and that the sequence and structure of information presentation determines outcomes.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence (Kahneman): depleted users default to denial (parole judge study); each decision consumes from the same depleted pool. New evidence (Cialdini + John): John was cooperative during tenant evaluation but resistant during platform terms -- the two evaluations consumed different types of cognitive resources (familiar framework vs. unfamiliar framework), and mixing them caused the negative to overwrite the positive. Combined insight: depletion is not just about volume of decisions but about type mixing. A host who evaluates tenants using familiar criteria (low depletion) and then switches to evaluating unfamiliar platform terms (high depletion) experiences a category-switch cost that is worse than two evaluations of the same type. The two-layer separation is a specific implementation of the depleted-user principle for mixed-type evaluations.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the host's experience during the gap after a call. The library's Continuity Priming element prescribes that the agent mention the platform by name and describe what the host will see, so the digital experience feels like a continuation. This run's Specific Next Step Closure Block prescribes a structured WHO/WHAT/WHEN commitment at the end of every unresolved interaction. Both ensure the host has a clear mental model of what comes next after the call ends.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: the agent should say 'I will send you a link, and when you open it you will see your two apartments already started for you' to prime the digital transition. New evidence: Bryant said 'I can talk to our team' which gave John zero mental model of what comes next. Combined insight: the closure block is the vehicle through which continuity priming is delivered. Without a structured closure, even good priming earlier in the call is wasted because the last impression dominates. The closure block should include both the specific commitment AND the continuity prime ('I will call you tomorrow at 2 PM with a payment proposal, and I will also send you a link tonight where you can see Ariel and Amber's profiles').

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the speed and naturalness of interaction. The library's Match Platform Cognitive Speed to Conversational Speed prescribes that platform tasks should take no more than 50% longer than the equivalent conversational task. This run's Tenant Warmth Before Platform Mechanics prescribes protecting the warm, human evaluation phase by keeping the host in the interpersonal mode as long as possible before introducing business mechanics. Both recognize that the human interaction is the benchmark the platform must meet or exceed.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas described two units in 7 seconds; the platform must match this conversational density. New evidence: John was warm and cooperative when evaluating tenants as people (02:12-03:50) but cold when evaluating platform mechanics (05:40+). Combined insight: 'speed' is not just clock time but emotional rhythm. The platform must match not only the conversational pace of the call but also the emotional sequence: human connection first, business mechanics second. Speed without warmth feels clinical; warmth without speed feels inefficient. Both must be present.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address how financial information should be framed. The library's System 1 Trust Gate prescribes using familiar language and visual consistency. This run's Reframe Financial Advantages Through Social Norm Language prescribes presenting financial advantages in social norm language ('here is what NYC hosts do') rather than pure economic language ('you get $6,000 instead of $3,000'). Both recognize that the framing of information matters more than the content when System 1 is evaluating it.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: System 1 evaluates based on associative coherence -- unfamiliar terminology triggers threat response. New evidence: John ignored a doubled deposit because the financial framing could not penetrate the social norm violation. Combined insight: financial information must pass TWO automatic checks -- the System 1 visual/linguistic check AND the social proof check. Financial data presented in economic language may pass the first check (it looks professional) but fail the second (no peers validate it). Financial data in social norm language passes both.

contradictions.conflict: The library's Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust element prescribes that the platform should NOT be mentioned prominently during the call -- the agent should frame it as 'I will send you a link' rather than 'go to splitlease.com.' The agent maintains personal trust. This run's Payment Model Preview in First-Touch Materials prescribes including the payment timing in pre-call outreach materials (emails, texts), which necessarily surfaces platform mechanics before the human relationship is established. There is a tension between 'let the human build trust first' and 'seed the payment timing before the call.'
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The library's evidence is from a successful call (Andreas) where human trust was built first and then bridged to digital. This run's evidence is from a failed call (John) where the payment timing arrived too late and caused rejection. John's call provides stronger evidence that the late reveal is worse than an early preview -- the cost of surprise outweighs the cost of reduced human-first priming. However, the preview must be minimal (one sentence) and paired with property-specific relevance to avoid triggering premature rejection before the human relationship is established.
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve by sequencing: pre-call materials include a one-line payment timing preview ('guaranteed payment within 24 hours of check-in') alongside property-specific match information, so the host processes the timing in a context of relevance, not as a cold platform disclosure. The human call then deepens the relationship and provides the social proof. The payment preview seeds the concept; the call provides the evidence. Both elements remain valid but must be ordered correctly.

contradictions.conflict: The library's System 1 Trust Gate prescribes visual consistency across phase transitions -- same vocabulary, same UI patterns, no surprises. This run's Peer Proof Card Visual Identity introduces a visually DISTINCT component (warm surface background, green left border, mono font for similarity markers) that is unlike any other card type in the system. There is a tension between 'everything should look consistent' and 'peer proof must be visually distinct from platform information.'
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The library's evidence is about transition states -- the host should not encounter unfamiliar patterns at phase boundaries. This run's evidence is about content type -- the host must instantly distinguish peer evidence from platform marketing. Both are valid, but they apply to different design layers. Visual consistency applies to structural patterns (navigation, layout, interaction models). Visual distinction applies to content categories (proof vs. marketing vs. data). The proof card is a new content category, not a structural change.
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve by defining the proof card as a recognized design system component that is visually distinct but structurally consistent. Once introduced, it appears in the same position and with the same behavior across all phases, satisfying the System 1 consistency requirement through predictable placement even though its visual treatment differs from standard cards. Add the proof card to the design system documentation as a first-class component so it becomes familiar through repetition.

extensions.gap_filled: Social proof generation and retention flywheel. No existing library element addresses the systematic conversion of successful hosts into social proof assets. The library prescribes trust-building and transition management but has no mechanism for building the evidence library that future trust-building depends on. This element fills the cold-start problem gap: how does the platform generate the social proof it needs to convince hosts like John?
extensions.confidence_note: Strong confidence from a single lens because the evidence is structural, not perceptual. Every host who completes a successful lease and is not converted into a testimonial is an objectively missed opportunity. The pattern will be reinforced by any lens that examines retention or acquisition economics.

extensions.gap_filled: Compact peer proof information architecture. The library has no element that specifies how social proof should be structured, sized, and positioned relative to the terms it validates. This element defines the peer proof card as an information unit with a specific hierarchy (similarity markers > outcome > term > financial detail) and a specific cognitive load constraint (25 words, 5-second scan). This fills the gap between knowing social proof matters and knowing how to present it.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The information hierarchy (similarity first, outcome second) is directly supported by Cialdini's wallet experiment (70% vs. 33% based on similarity) and by John's behavior (he processed norm-similarity before economics). However, the specific word count and scan-time targets (25 words, 5 seconds) are design estimates that need validation through usability testing.

extensions.gap_filled: Temporal sequencing of social proof relative to norm-breaking reveals. The library addresses what should appear at transitions but not the temporal micro-sequence within a single state change. This element specifies that peer proof must render BEFORE the norm-breaking term (300ms proof entrance + 400ms dwell + 250ms term entrance). No existing library element addresses sub-second render sequencing as a persuasion mechanism.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. The principle (proof before term) is strongly supported by Cialdini's theory and John's call evidence. The specific timing values (300ms, 400ms, 250ms) are interaction design estimates that need A/B testing. The 400ms dwell matches typical saccade-fixation timing but has not been validated in this specific context.

extensions.gap_filled: Explicit confirmation gate between evaluation types. The library prescribes decompression moments between phases but does not prescribe a hard gate that prevents Phase B content from rendering until Phase A is positively resolved. This element introduces the concept of a DOM-level gate -- Phase B is not in the DOM until the host confirms Phase A. This is a stronger intervention than a visual separator or decompression moment.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence that the two-phase separation is needed -- John's call provides compelling evidence of the contamination pattern. The specific implementation (DOM-level gate, confirmation checkpoint) is one possible approach. A softer approach (visual separation with suggested but not required confirmation) might be sufficient and less disruptive. Needs testing.

extensions.gap_filled: Live countdown timer on unresolved interaction states. No existing library element addresses the real-time tracking of platform commitments to the host. The directed closure card with a live countdown creates accountability on the platform side and certainty on the host side, filling a gap between 'promise to follow up' and 'actually follow up with visibility.'
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence that structured closure is needed -- Bryant's vague handoff is the strongest single failure point in the call. The countdown timer is a specific implementation that adds urgency but could also create anxiety if not calibrated correctly. The per-minute update cadence (not per-second) is designed to mitigate this, but needs user testing.

extensions.gap_filled: Explicit norm validation before norm disruption as an emotional design principle. The library addresses cognitive continuity (System 1 trust) and depletion (ego depletion) but does not address the specific emotional threat of professional identity challenge. John's rejection was not cognitive overload or visual inconsistency -- it was professional pride under threat. This element fills the gap between cognitive design and emotional design for experienced, norm-committed hosts.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. John's emotional trajectory (businesslike > guarded > firm > dismissive) is clearly documented in the call transcript, and Cialdini's similarity principle explains why: the platform challenged his identity as an experienced NYC landlord without first validating it. This pattern will likely be reinforced by any lens examining experienced hosts with strong industry norms.

extensions.gap_filled: Peer belonging as an emotional design principle distinct from social proof as an information strategy. The library uses social proof as an information delivery mechanism (what to show). This element addresses social proof as an emotional experience (how the host should feel). The distinction matters: a host can process social proof information and still feel isolated if the emotional framing positions them as a solo adopter rather than a group joiner.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. John's use of 'what WE do in New York city' is unambiguous -- his identity is collective. The emotional cost of leaving that collective is higher than any financial incentive the platform offers. This element will be reinforced by any lens examining hosts with strong professional peer networks.

extensions.gap_filled: First successful transaction as the highest-leverage emotional design moment. No existing library element addresses the emotional design of the first payment notification. The library focuses on the pre-conversion journey (discovery through onboarding) and has thin coverage of active lease emotional moments. This element identifies the first payment as the moment where theoretical trust becomes experiential trust and the host converts from skeptic to potential advocate.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence from a single lens because the call never reached active lease -- the element is a forward projection based on John's reciprocal trust framework and Cialdini's infectious helpfulness principle. The principle is sound, but the specific design (ceremonial notification with timing comparison) needs validation from actual host post-payment interviews.

extensions.gap_filled: Similarity badge system for host-matched social proof. No existing library element specifies a visual mechanism for communicating host similarity dimensions in a scannable format. The badge system (pill-shaped mono labels with match-highlighting) fills the gap between having similar hosts in the proof library and making similarity instantly recognizable at a glance.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence. The principle (similarity must be instantly scannable) is strongly supported by Cialdini's 70% vs. 33% wallet experiment. The specific badge design (mono pills, matched vs. default states) is a design hypothesis that needs usability testing. The xs (11px) font size for badge labels is on the small side and may need to increase to 12-13px for accessibility.

extensions.gap_filled: Reciprocal commitment micro-actions after every host investment. No existing library element addresses the interaction-level rhythm of reciprocal exchange. The library prescribes feedback and decompression moments but not the specific pattern of platform-reciprocates-after-host-invests that John's 'both ways' framework demands.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. John's reciprocal trust model is explicitly stated twice in the call ('I trust him and they get, trust me too' and 'Because it's both ways'). Any experienced host with a strong sense of professional partnership will expect this reciprocity. The specific implementation (within 2 seconds, specific to host action) needs calibration.

new_tokens_flagged: proof-border-left: 3px solid accent (#2d5a3d) -- used in looks-001 for peer proof card left border
layer-transition-gap: 40px (xl) -- used in looks-002 for major information layer transitions
data-pill-bg: accent-light (#e8f0eb) with radius-full (9999px) -- used in looks-003 for key mono data point backgrounds
closure-card-border-left: 3px solid signal-info (#2d5a8a) -- used in looks-004 for next-step closure card left border
badge-matched-bg: accent (#2d5a3d) solid -- used in looks-007 for matched similarity badges
badge-default-bg: accent-light (#e8f0eb) -- used in looks-007 for default similarity badges
token_compliance.recommendation: Add all six tokens to the design system. The first four are component-level border and spacing tokens that extend existing primitives (accent, signal-info, accent-light, xl) into specific component use cases. The badge tokens (badge-matched-bg, badge-default-bg) introduce a new matched/default state pattern that should be standardized for any future badge-based component. None of these new tokens conflict with existing tokens -- they compose existing color and spacing primitives into semantic component tokens. Note: the looks elements reference token values from tokens.json correctly. The accent color (#2d5a3d) is the warm forest green from tokens.json, which aligns with the design system. However, per MEMORY.md, production uses a purple palette (#31135D) per the Style Guide. This token drift was previously detected. The new elements are consistent with tokens.json but will need reconciliation with the production purple palette when implemented.

journey_emotion_map.run_contribution: feels-004: peer belonging signal -- the host should feel they are being invited into a group of similar landlords, not pitched a product
feels-001: norm validation before disruption; feels-002: tenant warmth before mechanics; feels-004: peer belonging
feels-001: validate expertise before challenging norms; feels-003: certainty through specific commitment; feels-005: reciprocal commitment rhythm
feels-005: reciprocal commitment -- every host action meets a visible platform reciprocation
feels-001: validate existing norm before introducing alternative; feels-004: peer belonging at the highest-tension moment
feels-002: protect tenant warmth; feels-003: specific commitment on unresolved items
feels-005: ongoing reciprocal rhythm; feels-006: first payment as emotional conversion point
feels-004: evolved peer belonging -- the host now IS the social proof; feels-006: success experience compounds into advocacy motivation

arc_conflicts: Potential tension between feels-001 (validate the host's existing norm as legitimate) and the overall platform goal of getting hosts to accept a different payment model. If the validation is too strong, it reinforces the norm rather than creating space for the alternative. The copy guidelines attempt to resolve this by framing the alternative as an evolution of the norm, but the emotional risk remains: a host who feels deeply validated in their existing practice may be LESS willing to consider alternatives, not more. This needs careful calibration in copy testing.

The emotional arc from safety (evaluation) through excitement (tenant warmth) to tension (pricing) back to confidence (closure) is sound, but the drop from excitement to tension is steep when pricing arrives. The two-layer separation (behaves-002) helps by preserving the positive tenant evaluation, but the emotional transition from 'I like these people' to 'I don't like these terms' is the single most dangerous emotional moment in the journey. More emotional bridging may be needed between feels-002 and feels-001 -- the tenant warmth needs to actively carry through the pricing discussion, not just be preserved in a separate visual container.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc makes end-to-end sense with one critical vulnerability: the evaluation-to-pricing transition. The run correctly identifies this as the moment where professional identity threat is highest and provides both cognitive (two-layer separation) and emotional (norm validation before disruption) interventions. However, the arc depends on the tenant warmth (feels-002) being strong enough to survive the pricing collision, and John's call shows it was not strong enough in practice. The arc would be strengthened by an additional emotional element that explicitly connects the tenant warmth to the pricing discussion: 'Ariel and Amber are a great fit -- here is how landlords like you make that happen.' This bridges the emotional high of tenant evaluation into the pricing conversation rather than trying to insulate them from each other.

discovery.note: Coverage is thin because John was already past discovery when the call began. The elements for discovery are forward-projected from the call's evidence, not directly observed. Future lenses should target hosts who are in the actual discovery phase.

evaluation.note: Evaluation is the strongest-covered phase in this run because John's call is primarily an evaluation interaction. The two-layer separation pattern is well-evidenced.

onboarding.note: Onboarding coverage is strong because the call itself was the onboarding interaction, and the failure point (vague closure) generated multiple corrective elements.

listing_creation.note: John never reached listing creation. Coverage comes from the reciprocal commitment pattern projected forward. The library has existing coverage from earlier runs (works-002, works-003) that addresses listing creation directly.

pricing.note: Pricing is heavily covered because the payment timing rejection was the central event of John's call. The social norm framing elements are the strongest new contribution.

proposal_mgmt.note: Proposal management is well-covered because John's call was functionally a proposal evaluation with both tenant and platform-terms components.

active_lease.note: Active lease was never reached. Coverage is forward-projected from John's reciprocal trust framework and the first-payment conversion hypothesis. The library has stronger active lease coverage from guest-journey runs.

retention.note: Retention coverage is thin because John was lost at onboarding. The social proof flywheel element (works-005) and peer belonging element (feels-004) are the strongest contributions, but they are hypothetical for John's case. Retention needs a dedicated lens from a host who actually completed a lease cycle.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: Layer 1 (works) identified six process patterns, all centered on social proof delivery and information sequencing. However, it does not address the cold-start operational question: what does the platform do RIGHT NOW, before it has any similar-host testimonials? Works-005 (Convert First Successful Hosts into Social Proof Generators) addresses the long-term flywheel, but there is no short-term workaround element for the period when the proof library is empty.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Consider adding a process pattern for 'Social Proof Bootstrapping' -- how the agent and platform compensate for empty proof libraries. Options include: agent-as-proxy-proof ('In my experience working with NYC landlords...'), aggregate data proof ('Our NYC hosts average 18-hour payment turnaround'), and aspirational proof ('We are building a network of experienced NYC landlords'). These are weaker than matched testimonials but better than nothing.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: Layer 3 (looks) introduced seven visual patterns, all well-specified with tokens, contrast ratios, and hierarchy rules. However, none of the patterns have been tested for mobile responsiveness. The peer proof card (looks-001) at 16px internal padding with three-line content may work on desktop but could feel cramped on mobile. The similarity badge system (looks-007) at 11px mono text may be below comfortable reading size on mobile devices.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Re-examine looks elements with mobile viewport constraints. The peer proof card may need a stacked layout on mobile (badges above, outcome below) rather than the inline layout described. The similarity badges may need to increase from 11px to 13px for mobile legibility. All spacing tokens should have responsive variants.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: Layer 5 (feels) identified six emotional elements, but the emotional arc has a gap between feels-002 (Tenant Warmth) and feels-001 (Norm Validation Before Disruption). These two elements are designed to work sequentially -- warmth first, then validation before disruption -- but there is no bridging element that carries the tenant warmth INTO the pricing discussion. The current design preserves warmth in a separate container (via behaves-002's confirmation gate) but does not use it as active emotional fuel during the pricing negotiation.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Consider adding an emotional element: 'Tenant Warmth as Pricing Anchor.' The idea: when pricing terms are introduced, they should be explicitly framed in terms of the specific tenants the host already likes. Instead of 'payment arrives within 24 hours of check-in,' the framing should be 'payment for Ariel and Amber's first month arrives within 24 hours of their check-in.' Naming the specific tenants in the pricing context carries the emotional warmth across the layer boundary.
